awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute: Collaboration in Computing Infrastructure for Research and Education (CO-InResE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Computational science forms an essential component of scientific inquiry. It contributes to the advancement of research and development and boosts discovery speed. High-Performance Computing (HPC) and High Throughput Computing (HTC) enable scientific inquiry that was unthinkable just a few years ago while allowing the contribution from a range of research. Such advancement is also accomplished through multidisciplinary and multi-institutional contributions. This project will acquire, deploy, and maintain a 16 node HPC cluster, and support computing-intensive research and training across a wide range of disciplines. The new cluster is available as a campus-wide shared resource to Langston University and researchers across Oklahoma and beyond. 

The project aims to 1) Improve campus awareness and adoption of advanced computing and data resources for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) research and education activities; 2) Contribute to and enhance the current research computing resources at Langston University, the only Historically Black Colleges and University (HBCU) in the region; 3) Train a diverse cyberinfrastructure workforce; and 4) Actively contribute to the Open Science Grid gateway and the regional Cyberinfrastructure Consortium. The project facilitates a range of Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering research activities across campus. In addition, under served undergraduate students interested in joining the cyberinfrastructure workforce will be mentored and trained on all aspects of the job and career. This project has potential to advance the regional infrastructure and research efforts by sustaining and increasing the number of local resources across the region. Thus, it aligns with well-established regional distributed support teams such as the OneOklahoma Cyberinfrastructure Initiative.

The Program notes that this Area#4 in CC* was created explicitly to address computing needs at under served campuses. Langston University is a strong example, with an outdated computing resource and compelling needs for their proposed cluster. The project acquires a 16 node HPC cluster that will be deployed at Langston University. The proposed cluster, which consists of 768 Central Processing Unit (CPU) cores and 8 A100 Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) accelerators, will enhanced research and education at Langston University.

This project is funded through the collaborative efforts of the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (OAC) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Langston University (LU), the only Historically Black College and University (HBCU) in Oklahoma, has undertaken a transformative project aimed through the support of the NSF CC* title "Collaboration in Computing Infrastructure for Research and Education (CO-InResE)"at significantly improving its research and educational capabilities with High-Performance Computing (HPC) and High-Throughput Computing (HTC). This initiative has impacted and will continue to impact LU's research agenda and education initiative over the next decade, as defined by the National Science Foundation (NSF) merit review criteria.

Intellectual Merit: CO-InResE has empowered LU students and faculty with access to the latest and advanced computational resources, enabling groundbreaking research across various disciplines. By upgrading the 10-year-old Lucille at CCRE computing cluster and enhancing network infrastructure, researchers in Biochemistry, Biomedical Engineering, Chemistry, Computer Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering Technology, Mathematics, and Physics have gained even more powerful tools for a current research agenda. This will significantly advance various research areas and facilitate more impactful research projects.

Upgrading HPC resources has and will continue to enable the handling and processing of large datasets. The capability has been pivotal in supporting research initiatives such as the Kansas/Oklahoma Wheat EPSCoR Project and the Nebraska/Kansas/Oklahoma MICRA EPSCoR Project, focusing on agricultural data analysis with food security and sustainability implications. The cluster will allow the LU team to continue with their STEM workforce activities through students and faculty hands-on training in Linux, Python programming, and Data Science.

The LU's participation in the Open Science Grid (OSG) community and regional communities such as OFFN and OneOCII has been and will continue to be critical to this project's success. By joining OSG, LU will continue to be able to collaborate with a vast network of researchers and institutions, sharing computational resources and expertise. This partnership will continue to enhance the university's ability to conduct high-impact research and provide researchers with access to a broader range of computational tools and data.

Broader Impacts: The impacts of CO-InResE are multifaceted and far-reaching. It will continue to serve as an incubator for new research, collaboration, and the potential development of innovative products. The project has fostered a culture of continuous learning and professional growth by providing training and development opportunities for faculty and students. The project will continue to be instrumental in ensuring that all participants can effectively leverage the new computational resources in their areas of interest. By involving the entire community, the project will continue to create a dynamic space where knowledge and skills are shared, ultimately enhancing the university's academic and research profile.

Additionally, acquiring new HPC equipment has catalyzed improvements to the campus network infrastructure, ensuring connectivity across all buildings and student dorms. This enhancement is crucial for meeting the HPC/HTC demands and enabling seamless data transfer from any location on campus. With these updates, LU's campus wide network is now prepared for 100Gbps connectivity, supporting the growing computational needs of the university.

The project is built on previous experience and will continue to have significant impacts by preparing underserved students to pursue careers in HPC-related fields. Hosting this project at LU provides students and faculty with access to advanced instruments they might not otherwise encounter, fostering a unique learning environment that significantly enhances their academic and research capabilities. This exposure is crucial for underserved students, allowing them to gain hands-on experience with cutting-edge technologies. By integrating these resources into their education, the project prepares students for potential careers in HPC-related fields and broadens their horizons, encouraging them to explore and excel in STEM fields.

Finally, the enabled multidisciplinary projects will potentially impact the entire LU community through various outreach activities, regardless of individual interests. These initiatives are designed to engage students, faculty, and staff from diverse academic backgrounds, fostering a culture of collaboration and innovation. Through workshops, seminars, and hands-on training sessions, participants will gain exposure to a wide range of disciplines and cutting-edge technologies. This inclusive approach broadens the educational experience and encourages interdisciplinary research and problem-solving.

Conclusion: This CO-InResE project has been a game-changer for Langston University. It has provided students and faculty with access to advanced computational tools and prepared underserved students to pursue careers in HPC. This project has elevated LU's research profile and contributed to the broader academic and scientific community by equipping researchers with the necessary skills and resources. Ultimately, this initiative will have a multidisciplinary impact, benefiting fields such as STEM, agriculture, and the social and behavioral sciences. Through these efforts, LU will continue to make significant strides in fostering a diverse and inclusive environment for scientific inquiry and innovation.
